content.webTitle: ABC's Michelle Guthrie: I was never a 'Murdoch hatchet woman'

fields.headline: ABC's Michelle Guthrie: I was never a 'Murdoch hatchet woman'
fields.bodyText: Working for Rupert Murdoch for 14 years does not make her a “Murdoch hatchet woman”, ABC managing director Michelle Guthrie has said in her first in-depth television interview after 13 months in the job. Guthrie said she did not appreciate being called a Murdoch stooge or accused of “Google-ising” the ABC just because she had a long career overseas before being appointed to run the public broadcaster. “I do find that when it becomes very personal – particularly around being called a Murdoch hatchet woman – [it does hit me],” Guthrie said on ABC News channel’s One Plus One interview program. “I never felt that my role at [Murdoch’s] Star TV was remotely about being a hatchet woman; it was about building an incredible business across Asia. And the idea that I would come to want to join the ABC and have such a privilege of joining the ABC and wanting to disembowel it, it’s beyond ridiculous frankly.” The Australian-born Guthrie spent much of her career abroad after graduating with a law degree, starting at Murdoch’s Sky in 1994 and working at Foxtel before heading up Star TV in Asia. She says that because most people in Australia didn’t know who she was when she replaced Mark Scott last year, there was intense speculation about her motives. “When there is a vacuum people read a lot into your CV,” she said. “So they say ‘well your longest period of time was at News Corp you must have certain political views’ or ‘you came from Google so you are going to Google-ise the ABC. And neither of those were true.” Guthrie also revealed she was a very private person and did not enjoy the spotlight of Senate estimates or the media attention the job of running the ABC attracts. She shuns social media, but is on LinkedIn and occasionally Snapchat. After just four days into the job in 2016, she had to appear before Senate estimates, telling senators “I hope you appreciate it’s very early days for me to give you specific details of all my plans”. Her corporate career involved facing up to boardrooms but it had not prepared her for the scrutiny of appearing before Senate estimates and the glare of the cameras, she said. “In boardrooms you don’t necessarily have masses of photographers and cameras capturing every hair flick or other expression on my face,” she told interviewer Jane Hutcheon. Guthrie said her childhood in Sydney – as one of four children of a Chinese mother and an Australian father – was chaotic and untypical. She said she ate fried rice for breakfast and lived with three generations under the one roof. “There was always food, there was always noise, there was always a TV going.” She described herself as studious but indecisive about a career, shifting from wanting to be a paediatrician to wanting to be a 60 Minutes reporter like her idol Jana Wendt. She praised Four Corners and the recent Lindt Cafe investigation, and rejected criticism that the ABC was spending money on Google advertising. “It’s a crime to make great programs and not to tell people about it,” she said. Guthrie defended her statement earlier this year that it wasn’t her job to lobby for funding, saying the ABC was in a funding cycle and needed to use the money we have “to the best of our ability”. She hinted that the future might see the ABC gaining more partnerships with outside organisations and shaking up its traditional platforms. “I think of the ABC much more as an ecosystem than a standalone organisation and I do think the future will be much more of a partnership model.”
